content:
1ª 生福利部民國107年7月20日 部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
There are three of these International Centres. One of them, concentrating on sal onello and escherichia and therefore known as the International Salmonella and . Escherichia Centre, is under the direction of Dr F. Kauffmann at the Statens Serum- institut, Copenhagen. The other two, specializing in shigella and therefore known as the International shigella Centres, are directed respectively by Dr .H. Ewing at the Communicable Disease Centre, Atlante, USA, and by Lieutenant-Colonel H. J. Bensted at the Centrul public Health Laboratory, London, England. 1
At the invitation of the Director-General of the World Health Organization the Directors of the three International Centres, together with an expert nominated as * their representative by the International Association of Microbiological Societies (the IAls), met an a Consultant Group in London from 19 to 24 September 1955, in order to review the Centres' purposes and functions, and to advise on the best means of promoting further development and co-ordination of their activies. The IAMS representative was professor . Hormneche, of the Instituto de Higine, Montevideo, Uruguay, who is Chairman of the Enterobacteriaceae Subcommittee of the International Committee on Bacteriological Nomenclature of the IS.
The following observations are based on the review and recommendations of the Consultant Group.
ORIGINS OF THE INTERNATIONAL CENTRES, AND THEIR FORMAL RELATIONSHIPS TO WHO
The International Salmonella and Escherichia Centre, Copenhagen. This originated in 1938, with support from the Commonwealth Foundation of New York, as a Centre of more limited scope, the "International Salmonella Centre", at the Statens Seruminstitut, Copenhagen. In 1948 the Centre was taken over by WHO." Two years later the IAMS (then
1 Lieutenant-Colonel Bensted has since retired.
2 World Health Assembly Resolution / HAL. 24/, Off. Rec. Wid With Org., 15, 307 and 343; and Handbook of Resolutions and Decisions of the World Health Assembly and the Executive Board, third edition, 1956, p, 23
(2) 218 Ì
47
Academia Historic

There are three of these International Centres. One of them, concentrating on sal onello and escherichia and therefore known as the International Salmonella and . Escherichia Centre, is under the direction of Dr F. Kauffmann at the Statens Serum- institut, Copenhagen. The other two, specializing in shigella and therefore known as the International shigella Centres, are directed respectively by Dr .H. Ewing at the Communicable Disease Centre, Atlante, USA, and by Lieutenant-Colonel H. J. Bensted at the Centrul public Health Laboratory, London, England. 1

At the invitation of the Director-General of the World Health Organization the Directors of the three International Centres, together with an expert nominated as * their representative by the International Association of Microbiological Societies (the IAls), met an a Consultant Group in London from 19 to 24 September 1955, in order to review the Centres' purposes and functions, and to advise on the best means of promoting further development and co-ordination of their activies. The IAMS representative was professor . The following observations are based on the review and recommendations of the Consultant Group.
